mc_pro_critic_reviews.summary: Furious 7 is so entertaining that you don't notice Dwayne Johnson is missing from action much of the time, only that he kills it when he shows up.
Plot is unimportant. Family is everything, and Furious 7 is a blast.
It’s an enormous, steroidal blast, and as much ingenious fun as a blockbuster can be.

For all the full-throttle dazzle of Furious 7, the best scenes are the quietest ones, in which these characters make observations about love, life, and family that would seem overcooked in any other movie.

Like Lee Daniels' hit TV drama “Empire,” Furious 7 is stuffed with situations that require go-for-broke absurdity, but even Daniels and his nighttime soap predecessor Aaron Spelling would pause before attempting the level of “get the f—k outta here!” style shenanigans director James Wan and writer Chris Morgan employ.
Furious 7 is the best F&F; by far, two hours of pure pow fueled by dedication and passionate heart.

The series will doubtless continue on with Diesel, Rodriguez, Johnson, and the rest, but in the meantime, Furious 7 comes to the most conclusive and emotionally satisfying ending since, fittingly, the very first film.

What makes Furious 7 a serious contender for the title of Fast franchise highlight—challenged only by 2011’s Fast Five and its unmatched vault-heist sequence—is the way it embraces the series’ most basic pleasures while amplifying everything tenfold.
Furious 7 is the fuel-injected fusion of all that is and ever has been good in "The Fast and the Furious" saga.
Furious 7 never even pretends to be a stand-alone movie. This is a fan event through and through, filled with references, inside jokes and a loyalty to continuity that may baffle newcomers.

If incoming director James Wan (“The Conjuring,” “Saw”) falls the tiniest bit short of what Justin Lin brought to the third, fifth and sixth entries, Furious 7 nonetheless ranks a very successful fourth place overall, with at least one gargantuan set piece that ranks among the series’ finest.
A group more bulletproof than The Avengers, causing more mayhem than General Zod. Think Universal doesn’t have a superhero franchise? Think again.
Wan has fashioned a nitro-fuelled thrill-ride that forms a fitting tribute to its blue-eyed bro.
It's all dumb, but it's wonderfully, comfortably dumb in just the right way.
Finally, a movie with at least some coherence despite its sadly challenging circumstances.
Viewers who come for the spectacle will get their money's worth. Furious Seven is all about action, with some scenes being more inventive than others.

It's roughly as realistic as Georges Melies' "A Trip to the Moon," of course. But revisiting our old pals (one of whom is played by an actor who is no longer with us) and watching them survive one unsurvivable collision or plunge after another, continues against the odds to have a walloping charm all its own.
No one forks over 10 bucks to see one of these flicks for its logic. We go for the bananas demolition-derby mayhem. Furious 7 delivers that with the direct visceral rush of an EpiPen.
Furious 7 offers edge-of-the-seat excitement with outlandish action sequences, inventive stunts, hilarious cartoonish moments and even some touching emotion.

This is one of the most ridiculous thrillers I’ve ever seen, and yet even with a running time that stretched well beyond two hours, with so many repetitive moments I almost began to wonder if I had missed something and the movie had started again, I have to admit I was entertained by the sheer audacity of the car chases and battle sequences — and there were even some genuinely touching moments.
The film lays bare that the franchise's most radical asset is also its most conservative: an overriding emphasis on, above all else, the on-screen family.

Furious 7 kicks the biggest and hardest, but it’s far from the best. Lin has handed the keys to James Wan, the cunning horror director of "Saw" and "The Conjuring," and though the thrill isn’t gone, the finesse is.
There will no doubt be better movies released in 2015, but Furious 7 is an early favorite to win the prize for most picture.
It’s joyous, it’s crazy – cars skydive out of aircraft in Azerbaijan, no less  - it’s exhaustively long, and, still, it’s clunkily lovable.
Furious 7 provides both a satisfying chapter in the movies’ preeminent gearhead soap opera and a tactful, touching memorial to Walker.
Furious 7 is, to put it succinctly, a rush and a half.

Yes, the whole movie feels overstuffed and overlong, and the non-action scenes are often dragged down by stilted dialogue. But Furious 7 buzzes with a frenetic energy so contagious, there’s no sense in resisting it.

While it can feel, at times, a little too scattered (often in terms of plot), this is a praiseworthy venture. Its a film that knows its audience well enough to give them exactly what they demand and deserve after more than a decade of dedication.
In the wake of Walker’s death, it constitutes a farewell of fitting elegance.

Furious 7, formulaic or not, knows exactly what kind of movie it is. It is a superhero movie without the tights. It is a comic-book franchise without the radioactive spider bite. It is, plain and simple, an automotive "Avengers."
The sheer sense of ludicrous, punch-the-air joie de vivre is impossibly infectious.
There’s something about the franchise’s earnest investment in its characters that’s quite unique. Its longevity is because it functions as much as a soap as an action flick.

I’ve always enjoyed the idea of the Fast & Furious films more than their execution, but this feels like the series’ strongest, even though some of its action sequences are so muddled they can barely walk straight.

A film that (whatever massive efforts were required to work around [Paul Walker's] absence) is as stupendously stupid and stupidly diverting as it could have hoped to be had everything gone as planned.
The only grace note in this otherwise determinedly graceless movie is the classy way Walker’s exit is handled.
There's too much head-butting between human battering rams Diesel and Jason Statham, too many noisy explosions and generic special effects, and not enough car races and chases.

Cacophonous, gratuitous, and peppered with absolutely outstanding action sequences, Furious 7 finds the franchise at an unwanted crossroads, but it makes such a play for the diehard fans that it leaves everyone else at somewhat of a loss.

The reflection offered in the puckered muscle and polished chrome of Furious 7’s heroes feels like a cheery escapist distortion of a culture that more closely resembles the smashed steel, mangled bone and blood and vomit of a plain ol’ unsexy car wreck.
If you don’t crave the taste of motor oil on your popcorn, Furious 7 can’t end fast enough.

Here is a film in which nothing is at stake: Cars crash into each other head-on at high speeds, vehicles sail off cliffs and tumble down rocky mountainsides, people jump out of buildings and fall six stories to the ground, then characters just dust themselves off and continue as if nothing had happened. Even Wile E. Coyote wasn't  this resilient.
Despite James Wan’s capable direction and very game cast, the whole thing goes increasingly wobbly like a bad axle, until it’s just a tangle of metal and bullets and yelling.
The fun is in shorter supply. And all these gear-jamming chases and wince-inducing explosions cannot hide that this ride has long been on a road to nowhere.
If you like a little bit more in a movie — say, characters that are mildly interesting or a plot that's a wee bit logical — stay far away.

The action comes so fast and furious in Furious 7 that, for all the explosions and overturned cars and missiles fired on downtown Los Angeles, it becomes a dull muddle. Here and there, we get the imaginative and outrageous stunts this series is famous for, but mostly the movie plods along, muscling through without much life or spirit.

Furious 7 is the culmination of numerous chances to set the bar for high-octane action movies that comes together and makes for quite the ride.  Know that this movie doesn't focus on excellent dialogue and intricate plot development.  It's about cars, crazy people, bringing back the insanity of 80s/90s action movies, and the eventual sending off of Paul Walker.  The end sequence that uses Wiz Khalifa's "See You Again" is perhaps one of the most tender moment in movies I've seen in a long time, which is so amped up because Paul Walker was not present in the completion of filming this movie due to his unfortunate death.  Seeing a character that was digitally entered into scenes at times was incredible because I never knew the difference.  Furious 7 will certainly please the fans of the series, and if you're an action movie connoisseur then this is an easy recommendation.  Don't come looking for the next Jason Bourne or James Bond series.  This is just simple fun for audiences to chew up for two hours.

Well I finally got around to seeing this. It's definitely more of the same. I'm always eager to see how each new installment of this franchise will outdo the last in terms of ridiculous, over-the-top stunts and action scenes. Sure enough, this one manages to do it with a car jumping out of a window between two buildings (twice!), Paul Walker climbing out of a bus hanging over a cliff, etc. Regardless, it may be mindless, but it's also undeniably entertaining and has the same great cheesy dialogue, action, and charm we've come to know and love from the franchise overall. Also, the last five minutes of the film, in my opinion, is arguably the best part. You'll see why when you watch this.

I really enjoyed this movie. It was a very dumb movie but it was also a really fun watch. It knows what it is which is good enough for me, as long as the movies knows that it's dumb then I'm alright with that. Paul Walker's send off was also very touching.

Despite bad developed villains and an unnecessary appearance of Lucas Black, Furious 7 is by far the best film of the franchise. Great characters and a higher level of action, now with even more amazing car sequences. Script choices concerning O'Conner were correct and gave him a natural and plausible ending in the story that began back in 2001. Special effects are also stunning, specially in completing the remaining scenes of Walker. Seven is enough and another sequel, this time without Walker, won't be the same thing. Sometimes it's better to know when to stop and this is the perfect moment for it.

Furious 7 is a fast-paced, action packed thrill ride that has little regard for realism in its action, as it should be. Do some parts of the movie seem ridiculous? Yes. Does the comedy fall flat sometimes? Yes. Despite that, the plot holds well enough and there’s a lot of fun to be had in watching the fight/drive sequences, which is what matters most in a F&F; film. Lastly, kudos for the amazing send-off to Paul Walker at the end! Furious 7 is a good, fun movie that merits being watched some more.

I really wanted to like this movie. There haven't been many in the series that I thought were really good. The first one is by far the best in my opinion and I believe that it has to do with the more limited budget forcing more realistic car sequences and more believable action. These types of movies need to get back to the type of chases that made Bullet and the French Connection chases classics that people still talk about.

After Fast & Furious 6, I thought that we really didn’t need another F&F; movie. Add the fact that the plot of Furious 7 is just Owen Shaw’s brother (Deckard Shaw) seeking revenge, and Furious 7 seemed like a somewhat unwarranted movie. Not because I was tired of F&F; movies, but because I thought there was no reason (at least story wise) to keep making them. (Of course, there was still the mystery of who killed Han, but that’s beside the point.) Nevertheless, I was enticed by the trailers and TV spots for F7. The promise of more impossible car stunts and dumb, crazy action lured me in.

I'm honestly glad that this is the first entry to the Fast & Furious series I've had the patience to see to the end. I am now acutely aware that there was nary a worthwhile cinematic moment I have missed in the entirety of this seven-film-long franchise. Don't misinterpret what I'm about to say. I'm not going to be broad or **** around what I mean to say so as to avoid making diehard fans of this franchise angry. This is a BAD movie. Not a good movie. Not an average movie. Furious 7 is a BAD movie. My brutality is warranted, I assure you.

We were very exhausted after watching this movie of non-stop action. We also always love how Letty can be sexy and tough. Of course, we were trying to figure out when it was Paul Walker or when it was one of his brothers. Similar to "Raintree Cointy" trying to figure out which scenes were after Montgomery Cliff's horrible car accident. But you can't tell about Paul. They did a great job with a wonderful send off to Paul. We can now watch his other movies remembering him fondly and as if we knew him. For a movie with so much action, it also has much sentiment which is sorely needed to balance the movie and make the franchise worth watching for different personalities.

Number 5 was best because the story made you think. This movie, like #6, has very little story but lots of action. Good movie that could have been great if the movie makers spent more time on story instead of crazy and unbelievable action scenes, how many times does Vin Diesel crash full speed into stuff before we say "come on, give me a break!"

As ridiculous as it's always, James Wan steps in with a lot of surprise without revealing much in the trailers for the Furious fans base, proofing that the risk of franchise fatigue can be excluded as long as the the story keeps moving into new directions. The story succeeds by maintaining perfectly the racing cultures, hilarious fun and unstoppable action sequences from its predecessors, expanding into an explosive scale that audiences might feel that it owns some shades of Mission Impossible and The Dark Knight trilogy. Engagement achieved in this 15-year-old franchise plays an essential factor in delivering unexpected plot, good performance, characters development, cinematography, stunning visual effects, thrilling races and blasting fight; even Brian Tyler puts in an extreme heartfelt effort to bring more stylish, adrenaline-driven, impulsive yet emotional soundtracks. This seventh attempt of speeding appears to be the best entry since Fast 5, with an exception that the beautifully crafted ending may seems perfect as the final film, not only triggering the tears of audiences, but also intentionally a metaphor farewell to beloved Brian O'Conner and an impressive tribute for Paul Walker.

Furious 7 delivers everything fans of the franchise desire. The same fun characters you’ve grown to love, beyond ridiculous action sequences and pays Paul Walker the farewell he deserves. While I didn’t enjoy it as much as 5 or 6, it’s still a very fun movie.

It's what you expect out of a F&F; film. I've never been a huge fan of the franchise, but this movie was quite entertaining. The plot was ludicrous and quick, the stunts were crazy, the acting and comedy were fine, and it was unrealistic, but it is a good popcorn flick that will keep your eyes glued to the screen because of all this. I thought this could have been a cash grab off of Paul Walker's death, but this movie proved to be more than that and probably the best film of the franchise. An emotional final tribute to Walker also showed how much heart the cast actually tried to put into this film. Overall, it ain't a must-see, but its a solid and entertaining film that I would recommend to anyone, fan or not.

This film was the best one of the fast and furious franchise so far. I felt after fast 6 they were done because the last one was a bit off and boring but this film took it to the next level and was an absolute blast. The action was amazing and the stunts were ridiculously AWESOME, silly and just great fun to watch. The plot was simple and straight forward "find the bad guy and trap him before he finds you". However the chemistry between Dom and letty was weird and a bit off especially in the last act which really didn't work for me, statham was wasted he was a good villain like the winter soldier just popping up everywhere, but didn't get enough screen time and therefore wasted. The role of Tyrese Gibson was amazing he is the best comic-relief I have ever seen anytime he opened his mouth I laughed. The role of Nathalie As Ramsey was a bit sketchy and finally Paul walker's tribute was emotionally great and I almost cried. All in all a great film, great characters, action/stunts and a wonderful sendoff to Paul walker.
As far as F&F; standards go, this movie is a big letdown.

It just keeps on getting BIGGER, BETTER, FASTER and CRAZIER!!! Easily the best movie in the franchise so far and seems like they merged all of the past movies together to create this behemoth. This awesome epic is filled with ACTION, CARS, WOMEN, FIGHTING and MUSCLES. It is constantly shouting at you and is the most spectacular action movie I have seen. In the past Fast and Furious movies there was one big job at the end of the movie but in Furious 7 there is a sequence of big events and the long run time is definitely worth it. Jason Statham brings what this franchise needed: a rememberable, badass villain and Tyrese Gibson brings back that comedy vibe with funny jokes and humour. I was a little disappointed not to see more of the Rock however but this mega cast has great chemistry and history. The movie is topped off with an emotional tribute to Paul Walker. The only real negative is that I am unsure how they will top this amazing movie for Furious 8 and be sure to catch it in the cinema for the best experience.

Its hard to believe that this series has reached a seventh instalment, especially if you remember the first two films. All pretence about being about street racers has long been forgotten and the films are now more like James Bond crossed with Ocean's 11. The stunts have got bigger, the locations more exotic and the plots more outrageous. Furious 7 involves some tosh about Jason Statham looking for revenge from the gangs exploits in London and a computer chip that is bizarrely hidden in a car on the 34th floor of a tower block in Dubai. It makes no sense whatsoever and has plot holes you could drive all the cars through more than once, but there is no denying it's hugely entertaining and a suitable send off for Paul Walker.

An Easter weekend cinema-going of this topical car-chasing no brainer, a franchise has already exceedingly overstayed its shelf-life, reaches an unforeseen acme catalysed by the tragic loss of its co-leading man Paul Walker last year (ironically in a car crash, again a bloody testimony of "movies are deceitful”, considering in this latest offering, no lack of crashes, but not even a minor concussion incurred or whatsoever.). After the series best FAST FIVE (2011, 7/10) and a degenerative FAST AND FURIOUS 6 (2013, 6/10), this time, the director chair has been delegated to James Wan, the master-hand behind SAW & INSIDIOUS horror trademarks, it is a sure-thing its box office will explode and achieve another series-high, but reckoning a story and cast overhaul is inevitable for its next move, let us take it as a sincere eulogy not only to Paul but the franchise itself.

, combined with a great sense of fun, and fast paced action sequences make Furious 7 a great example of dumb fun done right. Perhaps the greatest strength of Furious 7 is that it takes the stunts of the last film and ups the ante even more. Even more impressive is that

This film was horrendously made. The fights scenes, especially the one between Jason Statham and Dwayne was terribly done. The video has a strobe effect like the DP messed with the shutter speed so you can't see clearly what is going on. The fights are a big blur and you can't see anything clearly. The editing just cuts between cameras extremely fast so you have to imagine the fight in your mind because you can't see it on the screen. This is the opposite of the Film Equalizer with Denzel Washington, were you can clearly see the combat, in crisp visceral detail. Not this BS!

Best movie in the franchise. All the original elements are retained and added is big time stunts and outrageous action. This is how a franchise should evolve in my opinion. Yes I miss the CGI free action of the early movies, in particular the original, but a series needs to grow.

At times the action in Furious 7 can be perceived as overwhelming, but isn't that what the Fast and Furious movies are all about. This by far was the best one yet. The star line-up was phenomenal, every theatre was packed no matter what show time. There's no doubt this movie will probably the one of the most highest-grossing movies of 2015. In addition the 3 minute tribute will leave you in tears if you have any type of soul.

Vin & Paul and everybody else is back for more international intrigue. These films used to be about racing, but they've slowly developed into action-filled missions to save the world with fast cars. After a sluggish start, this one slams on the accelerator and speeds thru one outrageous sequence after another. Forget the laws of physics, the viability of human endurance, even common sense…this film is all about stunts that are hilariously over the top. Don’t worry about plot or dialogue and enjoy the macho posturing. Even though it's sometimes hard to follow the geography of the fights, they're still hard-hitting and sprinkled with clever camera tricks. Go for the pure popcorn thrill to enjoy this wild and crazy ride!

The fact that the Fast and Furious series has become a billion dollar franchise is a big surprise form its humble beginnings.  More of the same, but with added emotional gravitas due to the loss of main star Paul Walker halfway through the shoot.  So much that his departure from the franchise was handled quite beautifully in its last 10 minutes, that every grown, 'macho' men (including Diesel himself) will get teary eyed.  Other than that, great, absolutely bonkers action sequences are worth the price of admission alone.  Another great entry in the franchise.

This is the best movie in the franchise. It has a lot of action and thrills but mostly a lot of heart. I'm glad that the director took the film in that direction after the accident Paul Walker was in. I pray that Paul is in Heaven looking down upon us all.
Furious 7 is the title of the best in the series in my opinion. The film even managed to be a very good one end of the film even made me cry. RIP Paul Walker.
and this undoubtedly the best film in the series or action along with race I have ever seen in my life fantastic history adrenaline the ending was sad emociante the honor of Paul Walker

Furious 7 is an incredible action film - big budget, entertaining and stylish. Plus, the way they treated Paul Walker's passing created an emotional element to the story. This film is a a true cinematic epic, loaded with A-list actors. The only trouble is the length of the film (LONG!), and the unrealistic action sequences, sometimes - they tend to be a tad off-putting. However , director James Wan and producer Vin Diesel have made an excellent picture, which will certainly turn a handsome profit for Universal.

I have recently rediscovered the Fast and Furious franchise after being alienated by 'Tokyo Drift' and therefore do not have the emotional attachment of a diehard fan. However FF7 was absolutely fantastic, it did exactly what it said on the tin- providing adrenaline fuelled action throughout. People who say it is mindless rubbish completely misunderstand the franchise and this film. One must take it for exactly what it is, not get too perplexed by the constant breaking of the laws of physics and just sit back and enjoy the ride (pun intended).

Best out of all. This is a must see movie in theaters. Acting was great. Plot was great. You felt for every actor and played there rolls perfectly. I was pumped from start to finish and made me want to see the next one. No  questions unanswered. So far the best movie of the year of its kind. R.I.P  P.W. You will be missed.

It takes a lot to find solace as a director in both the cramped, disquieting corners of a horror movie set and the daunting, frenetic dimensions of a high-octane action film. It's safe to say that James Wan can. "Furious 7" is a well-configured sendoff(?) to the "Fast" franchise and easily the best installment within it, featuring superior set pieces, more organic character development tactics, and one of the most touching ending sequences to an action film I've watched in quite a while.

Best movie in the franchise hands down. Ridiculous stunts, check. Amazing action scenes, check. A-list actors, check. And the ending is extremely emotional and heart-warming. Loved this furious flick and definitely recommend, check.

After the fifth movie took the series in a new direction it became stronger than ever. This 7th entry in the series had some potential obstacles in it's path. Not only  was this director James Wan's first action movie, but actor Paul Walker (R.I.P.) died before they were finished filming (forcing this to be the farewell entry to his character) Luckily both of those things prove not to be an issue. James Wan shows incredible talent as a director of action films, and we getting a fitting conclusion to the story of Walker's character.

Furious 7 is as loud, over-the-top and bonkers an action film as you could ever want. Jason Statham prowls around like a tiger, beating seven shades out of anyone and everything. The stunts are so insane that they make you laugh out loud in the best way. Just dumb stupid fun and a great time. And then, of course, the last few moments will make you tear up big-time with one of the most emotional send-offs ever. Excellent stuff.

Over... the... top... Way too much unbelievable stuff. It's okay if you do a few unreal things in a movie... but constantly? Anyway, despite the crappy story and over the top stunts... it was still decently enjoyable. So far gone from what FATF was though. It isn't about cars anymore...

It's the same film as every single one that has gone before. If you liked the others, you'll like this. However, it is objectively a poor film - poorly acted, obsessively loud, terrible cameos, pointless frames gratuitously focusing on female arses for no reason other than "just because", nonsense plot, a complete lack of story continuity, with obviously dead characters suddenly not being dead - again, "just because"...

Who knew that the Fast and Furious franchise would reach seven movies? If you expect to see a Street Racing movie then you're wasting your time but still the movie is really fun and delivers what it promises.. Action , Stuns , Cool Cars and racewars!! But Furious 7 is not only fast cars and action. It's a tribute to Paul Walker. The tribute in the end is simply amazing and it will bring tears. Other than that there's nothing else to say.. Acting is pretty much the same as all the other movies , the roles remain the same and Vin Diesel delivers some "epic" lines.. 10/10 second best Fast and Furious movie...

This is probably one of the worst movies I have ever seen. Realism out the window, crap acting, upright mockery of car interested people, and probably worst of all; the shaky camera, low focus, piss poor fight sequences.

The main focus in the movie is to obviously provide an experience that'll help us remember the wonderful Paul Walker. From beginning to end, tons of action is present - mostly the type of action that I enjoy... a lot! There's just more girls, more cars, more explosions and stuff. The thing is, it was just the feeling that this would be the last Paul Walker experience we'd get. Anyways, good stuff - watch it √
Racing, jumping from planes, shooting and explosions, expensive cars, sexy women... Everything we wanted from just another FaF movie.
En que momento llegamos a tener una franquicia de siete peliculas, con una octava en camino solo queda seguir disfrutando esta saga, lo mejor sin duda la despedida a Paul Walker.

This movie defies logic in every single away. You've got a car crossing over three buildings in a row, a man falling downhill after jumping from a building and surviving that, the bad guy that survives after being smashed by big wreckage. All of that seems incredibly unbelievable.... but it's so damn fun. The action is entertainingly over-the-top, the humor is actually pretty good and the homage they did to the late Paul Walker is well put together. One other problem I had with "Furious 7" -- aside from its silly story -- was Vin Diesel. I know a lot of people like him, but I found him to be particularly bland in this film. Shame "The Rock" didn't have much screen-time as he should have had.

At the end of the movie I could not stop the tears , let's be clear , not for moving tribute to Walker , but for all the action that my poor eyes have had to put up with . However , despite the brand is always the same , I think this chapter is the most solid of the whole saga , and perhaps the not credible action scenes found an environment more familiar to them .

Personally, I never thought this "Fast and Furious" series could actually be good. After three mediocre installments ('F+F', '2F 2F' & 'Tokyo Drift') and one that no one remembers ('F&F; 4'), one could think that they were going from down to low. But, 'Fast Five' and 'F&F; 6' things really begun to take flight. And, I never thought I'd say this, but "Furious 7" is a damn fine action film. It unashamedly defies logic, but the quality of the action sequences is stunning. And, there's no way you won't get the goosebumps in Paul Walker's first and final scene. "F7" is somewhat darker and grimmer, and there's something about James Wan's direction that makes the film breathe, unlike many of its peers. It's thrilling, exhausting and a heck of a lot of fun.

A decent film. Although, I can’t help but feel a bit fast and furioused out tbh. This is the seventh film in the series and for me the films aren’t offering anything different anymore that we haven’t already seen. Given Paul Walkers death I’d like to see the series end, however, according to Vin Diesel, Furious 7 marks the start of a finale trilogy. So two more films to go if that’s correct. Don’t get me wrong, this is a very watchable film with good action, a good cast and a strong enough story. But personally, I won’t be dashing off to the cinema for the next instalments.

This movie, finally, will be measured by asking the question: Did you cry during the Paul Walker tribute? For 'Furious' fans, the answer will almost always be yes. Walker was a signature to the franchise. They'll need someone just as good to keep the series vital. If you're a 'Furious' fan, don't miss this one...

If you are looking for easy going summer blockbuster, then this is the right choice. Action scenes are probably the best in the whole history of F&F.; Jason Statham is bad ass as usual and he fits perfectly into the world of F&F.; One thing which is a bit distraction is never ending Vin Diesel's talks about family values and obviously end of the movie in the spirit of saying goodbye to Paul Walker. Don't break your head with physical nonsense in the movie and just enjoy action which in everywhere in the movie.

Well let me be honest i don't like the franchise at all i came here expecting the worst but what i found was an entertaining movie that fortunately it doesn't take itself seriously and doesn't expect us to do either.The action was the best part of it the characters were awfull the acting could go from mediocre to unbearable the character interaction was fun and the whole the final scene is kinda sad and nostalgic for the fans considering the death of the actor Paul Walker.The again if you take this movie seriously like i tried to do prepare to meet some of the worst cliches pretictable plot points and generic music you've seen in your life.Cinematography is good and the director realy knew what he was doing the plot is non existent but as i said you better not take it seriously.All and all it was a fun film nothing special at all but still can be Enjoyed

A very forgettable installment in a long worn out franchise. Worth seeing if only for the few obligatory action sequences that push the bounds of realism. The tribute to Paul Walker at the end, though somewhat detached from the movie itself, did threaten to bring a tear to my eye however, and was a fitting goodbye. If only the movie had been a bit more worthy.

Absolutely amazing , a unique film compared to any other , what made this film so special and different is the fact that Paul Walker was carried throughout the film with the un-expected tragedy of his death (r.i.p Paul) , but this Fast And Furious film is action packed with the main villain 'Deckard Shaw' ( Jason Stathman) who is in an attempt to kill the F.B.I agent (Dwayne Joshnson) for 'crippling' his brother , Dominic Torreto is also in an attempt to kill the villain as he killed 'han' to get the real story you need to watch this , and this is a film I would definitely recommend to anyone above the age of 12 , definitely worth watching!!!!
I really had a good time watching Furious 7. The action scenes are kind of dumb but awesome anyway. Furious 7 is not my favourite one but I got a lot fun when I watched it.

The latest entry in the fast and furious series is by far one of the most action packed one. With the plot taking a detour from the fast cars and heists the series seems to be going in a new and fresh way, Fast 7 also provides the perfect send off for the late Paul Walker

There is no denial that Furious 7 has been one of the most anticipated films of 2015.  With a legacy of 15 years, Furious 7 manages to still come out with a fresh and fun concept, while capturing the essence of the original.  Now the film has some extraordinary action scenes and moments involving our favorite characters, however there were some big problems as well. But let’s be honest, all the bad stuff can be forgotten due to how great not only Universal Studios was, but also director James Wan (The Conjuring) and the entire cast was with the passing of Paul Walker and all that it entailed.

Like everyone one before this I enjoyed this one too Furious 7 did not disappoint me.  I find this series so intriguing because not only do I love the story line of family but I also love the cars.  I am really excited for how the Fast 8 will turn out.  With Paul now being gone I think this series will take a great turn.  The salute to Paul and the music that followed were a perfect ending to a great movie.

This new chapter of fast & furious franchise directed by James Wan ( Conjuring and insidious fame) is a good movie fully packed with thrilling action sequences like its predecessors.The expectations were so high and the main reason would be the fact that the Paul Walker is no more  to act in anymore films.When paul walker died due to car accident few months back, this film was only half way through shooting.

This was a great leap for the cast and crew of The Fast and the Furious franchise cast and crew, as you would expect, the story seemed the same but different in it's own way. The cast had given it's greatest performance in the series, and gladly enough they had given Paul Walker his memorable and groundbreaking final performance as Brian O' Conner a proper farewell, which probably made some people shed some tears in the final moments of the films. The series is very well know to repeat the story in future projects, which would be awesome.
A fun and enjoyable film you can rent with your family and enjoy on a weekend night but not incredibly rewatchable. One viewing should probably be enough to satisfy anyone.

Okay, so i'm not the biggest Fast and Furious fan. However, I did enjoy the first film and the past two films. Although this film didn't change my mind about not being the biggest Furious fan, this was still a bloody enjoyable flick. The action scenes are so crazy stupid and, considering the production troubles (because of the loss of Paul Walker), the film still held up pretty well. Not having Dwayne Johnson in it much was a bit of a let down, but, nonetheless, that ending made up for it (no spoilers!). My final thoughts on this would be:

I can understand why a movie like this would be bashed however, it is successful for a reason. Furious 7 is entertaining and there is no denying that. If you are calling this movie "unrealistic", you've watched it for the wrong reasons and should be informed that the it's unrealistic nature is intentional. The Furious franchise is fun, action-packed and never fails to entertain. Keep 'em coming!

The Fast and Furious franchise showcased not only cool ideas on how cars can be showcased in the film but also the nature of a family and what you will sacrifice just for their safety. I loved the Lykan Hypersport stunts but I got bored in the final showdown that I got a feeling of drowsiness (probably because the setting is nighttime and it was too dark, good timing for lying down and snore). This could be a great franchise-ender since one of its main characters are gone (RIP Paul).
No words to say. This movie is very very very very very very amazing, I can watch this over and over again. Just amazin as I say. Rating this 10 / 10 !

Like most of the FF series, this movie is a walking beer commercial full of fast cars and gratuitous shots of boobs and butts.  Vin Diesel does his usual earnest bad-ass routine but the acting is so bad all the way around that it can only be blamed on the direction.  I shouldn't be too hard on films like this as I'm sure they connect with their target audiences comprised mainly of Charger Hellcat owners I'll bet.  It's just depressing to think that millions of people are actually entertained by this crap.

Furious 7 is car that falls behind for much of the race letting cars labeled 6 & 7 take the lead until the final stretch where it puts on the gas. In the final stretch the fun and energy that had given it victory in the past come full force. While it does finish first like I would’ve hoped the climax combined with a touching and not forced send off to Aaron Paul make this a bittersweet last ride.
Not very good... boring, plot was thin, background music overload, action overdone, acting average.

Worst movie I have ever seen and not in a good way like trolls 2. Probably the dumbest plot, terrible action, horrible acting and script. The constant terrible one liners make your head shake. Surprising I always enjoyed the fast and furious movies, even tokyo drift was light years better than this but this was just brutal to watch. The stupidity overload was just too much in one movie.

Jeez, I couldn't get through the first 15-mins of this fight/race/explosion turd! What the @#$! went wrong with this franchise?! I'll tell you. It's directed by a nobody whose recent credits include "Insidious 2" and "The Conjuring". Who thought getting THAT guy would be a good idea for an F&F; film?! At least the director for upcoming "Fast 8" has credits like "The Italian Job" and "The Negotiator" (setting aside "Straight Outta Compton", don't like where that would take "Fast 8"). There are many negatives here lamenting the two hours of life they want back, but I count myself fortunate for only losing 15-mins.

For a film named Fast and Furious it is interesting just how slow and pedestrian this film tends to be. It takes an awfully long time to get anywhere or say anything. And I primarily blame James Wan for this, I really don't think he has much directorial talent and is yet to direct a film that wasn't too long. But Furious 7 does have some decent set pieces although the cgi is ropier than you'd imagine for a film with this budget. I love Dwayne Johnson and Jason Statham no matter what the film is, and the Paul Walker montage at the end was genuinely moving. But overall meh.
This is a very simple review:

Furious 7 is in my opinion the best of the franchise so far. Really fun in a self-aware way and the Paul Walker tribute is amazing! Not going for awards, it's aiming for you to have a good time and for me it did just that.

And the most basic and generic franchise of all time keeps going with yet another spectacular but empty and boring chapter. As always, a bunch of mediocre (or just bad) actors being the face of a too long roller-coaster with no depth and ridiculous and sugar-coated dialogues. No matter how crazy and good some action scenes are, when you can not care at all about anything that happens to anyone in a film and there´s no sign of decent story anywhere, it is just boring. Which feels like a total waste of so much money (the money that costs making these big films). How I wish quality blockbusters would be the ones topping the box office and not this.
Same washed out formula for the 7th time. Ridiculous, over the top action and a lame story. Has some good actors but thats about it. Wasn't really worth the time spent.

Furious 7 drives on a impossibly narrow stretch of plot; but being part of the Fast & Furious franchise which doesn't exactly abide to the Laws of Physics, just about manages to scrape through. Perhaps it's strongest point is how, given the amount of over the top stunts it contains, still manages to deftly handle Paul Walker's character in an unavoidably emotional last several minutes. R.I.P Paul Walker.
Furious 7 maybe the best title of the Fast and Furious franchise so far, as it was awesome, with fast-pace action and a lot of crazily amazing new ideas, and an acceptably emotional story.

Awaiting the movie with great anticipation, knowing it will probably be the last of the franchise and that it has to tie up all loose ends somehow, there is no disappointment. For the 7th Sequel it holds its own and is very exciting to watch with a perfect cast. A big nod to Mr. Statham.

Furious 7 is just like the past 6 movies in the series is all about the action/entertainment and as long as you don't forget that well watching the film you may enjoy it, But you will have to suspend your believe in reality slightly. The cars and the action in this Film is just as ridiculous as it always is, With tons of destruction and extremely nice cars all over. The action that takes place out of the cars is a bit better this time around but still just as unrealistic as the rest of the movie. Furious 7 does a decent job at being a action popcorn flick but don't expect much past that, The movie tries to have a big emphasis on "Family" But doesn't really make you feel much. All in all if you know what the Fast&Furious; series offers you know what your getting into,It's Fun for  a weekend flick with buds but not something you'll watch over and over.

Where I could enjoy most of the furious movies I really disliked this one. Being over the top is fine, being total ridiculous is not. The movie was filled with interesting characters but there acting was overshadowed by explosions that would have put even Michael Bay to shame.

Like all the other Furious movies, this one features overwrought, melodramatic dialogue along with so-so acting and absolutely spectacular action/stunt scenes. They tried to dress it up with some interesting new characters provided by Jason Statham and Kurt Russell and a few others. It's fun to see director James Wan do something other than horror films. This one is pretty good and fits in well with the others.

The thing with Furious 7 is that you have to walk into it knowing that its sole purpose is to keep you entertained. its filled with the most unrealistic maneuvers and corny one liners you could ask for but that is the films charm and why it has an 8th in development. it does a great job of inviting you into its universe and taking you for the ride. At the end of the day I was extremely entertained and satisfied with the final result.

the usual thing that is expected from a Fast and Furious movie; Bad plot, wooden & horrible acting and over the top and ridiculous CGI car chases. Furious 7 deserves at most a 7. It's just the same thing over and over again, it's getting real old, they're making this franchise way too long, i can't believe people still watch it, i can't believe i watched it, probably because Paul Walker passed away so every one feels sad not to watch it. Truly one of my new favorite movies. Let me be honest, I'm hard to please in film, especially with action films like this. Soundtrack was great. Dwayne Johnson (whom I know from San Andreas) did a heck of a job in this. The ending was dramatic, with the tribute and all, but the entire film is worth a watch. :)
